_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CHERRY GROWERS INC - GRAWN, MI

                              

                    RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



















































                  RMP Communication Package

                     Cherry Growers Inc

                       Grawn Michigan

                          1/1/2004

                              

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Cherry Growers Inc

Grawn, MI







Background Data



In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal

Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR) promulgated by the

Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Cherry Growers Inc

submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at

their Grawn, Michigan facility.  Cherry Growers, Inc

operations include manufacture of frozen products for public

consumption packaged under the familiar brand names such as

Cherry Growers Inc.  Cherry Growers, Inc has been in

operation at this facility for 29 years providing quality

frozen products and over 145 jobs to the local community.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy



Cherry Growers, Inc is committed to protecting the health of

its employees, the surrounding community, and the

environment.  It is Cherry Growers, Inc policy to maintain a

safe and healthy workplace protect the environment, and

comply with all applicable regulations, including 40 CFR

and, as applicable, Occupational Safety and Health

Organ

ization (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM)

regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal

Regulations, Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR), and OSHA's

Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29

CFR).



Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances



Cherry Growers, Inc operates freezers and coolers for

product and ingredient storage.  Cherry Growers Inc uses

anhydrous ammonia (the 112(r) regulated substance) as a

refrigerant to maintain the 274,300 ft2 facility within the

required range of operation temperatures and to operate the

freezers and coolers.  Anhydrous ammonia is an industry-

standard refrigerant for food processing plants.  Cherry

Growers, Inc refrigeration system, consisting of receivers,

compressors, evaporators, condensers, and piping, and can

contain a maximum amount of 16,149 pounds of anhydrous

ammonia.









Worst Case Release Scenario



As required by 40 CFR, Cherry Growers Inc has evaluated a

worst-case release scenario for anhydrous ammonia using the

parameters specified by the EPA.  The worst-case release

scenario is defined as the release of the entire contents of

the largest single vessel over a 10-minute period.  Based on

Cherry Growers, Inc refrigeration system, the worst case

release scenario for anhydrous ammonia is defined as the

release of the entire contents of the largest single vessel

(a receiver) containing 10,000 pounds of ammonia when filled

to 90% capacity, the maximum fill capacity allowed by Cherry

Growers, Inc operating and engineering controls.  Using the

EPA's RMP comp program the maximum distance to the specified

"endpoint" (a conservative distance established by EPA at

which it is expected that a person could be exposed to the

chemical for an hour without suffering irreversible health

effects) includes offsite receptors.



The worst-case release scenario was developed following EPA

regulations and is not considered by Cherry Growers, Inc to

be a likely re

lease scenario for the facility.  During

normal operations, Cherry Growers, Inc maintains the

receivers have the potential to be filled to 90% of

capacity.  The receivers are operated in pump-down mode 1%

of the time during the year.



Alternative Release Scenario



A more realistic release scenario (alternative release) was

developed by Cherry Growers, Inc taking into consideration

the 29 year history of operation's experience and the

hazards identified in the process hazard analyses (PHA's)

conducted to ensure that Cherry Growers, Inc hazards are

identified and minimized.  These analyses were conducted in

accordance to Occupational Safety and Health Organization

(OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations

promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations

Chapter 1910, Section 19 (29 CFR).



After reviewing the process hazard analysis performed on the

system (in accordance with Cherry Growers, Inc process

safety management program), a more credible release scenario

would be a release caused by rupture of a <" high pressure

liquid pipe and a reasonable response time from the

facility's HazMat team.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous

ammonia, Cherry Growers, Inc has implemented several

precautionary measures that include process/equipment

controls, procedures, preventive-maintenance programs,

employee training, and audit programs.  In addition, the

ammonia refrigeration system itself is designed and

constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 Standard for

Equipment, Design, And Installation of Ammonia Mechanical

Refrigerating Systems (facility to verify).



Cherry Growers, Inc has also developed and implemented a PSM

program pursuant to OSHA regulations and as such, has

evaluated the system for the potential of anhydrous ammonia

releases.  Some of the controls installed to prevent

catastrophic releases of ammonia are process equipment,

(vents, pres

sure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual

shut-offs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs,

ammonia leak detection system, and electrical distribution

system grounding).  In addition, Cherry Growers, Inc has

trained approximately 4 personnel to respond to potential

ammonia releases (Emergency/Response team).



Cherry Growers, Inc has developed standard operating

procedures for all employees and contractors that have

contact with the ammonia refrigeration system that

incorporate safety measures into the procedures.  These

safety procedures were developed by refrigeration system

operators and are reviewed on an annual basis by means of

SOP review session(s).  Process safety information for the

refrigeration system is reviewed periodically as well.

Cherry Growers, Inc encourages employee participation in

development of the control measures used at the plant by

means of training sessions.  Pursuant to written management

of change procedures established by Cherry Growers, Inc any

changes to the operating procedures are to be communicated

to affected employees.



Cherry Growers, Inc understands that maintaining the

refrigeration system in good working order is essential to

preventing accidental releases; therefore Cherry Growers,

Inc has implemented a preventative maintenance program.

This preventative maintenance program is scheduled,

documented and managed using a computer maintenance

management software system to ensure that regular

maintenance occurs on the systems.  In addition, to ensure

Cherry Growers, Inc control measures are effective in

maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly

scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration

system.



u    In accordance with the PSM program, Cherry Growers, Inc

  conducts detailed PSM compliance audits every three years.

  Each audit incorporates review of process safety

  information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures,

  training programs, system

mechanical integrity, management

  of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit

  procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee

  participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and

  contractor safety procedures.



u    In addition, Cherry Growers, Inc is audited by the

  local fire department on an annual basis.



u    Cherry Growers, Inc is audited by the USDA and FDA on

  an annual basis.



u    Cherry Growers Inc insurance carrier also conducts

  independent audits on a semi-annual basis.











Five-Year Accident History



Over the last five years, Cherry Growers, Inc has

experienced only a minor on-site accidental release of

anhydrous ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system.

There were no off-site consequences.



Emergency Response Program



Cherry Growers, Inc has devised a comprehensive emergency

response program, designed to protect both employees and the

community in the even of a release.  This program is fully

described in a document entitled Emergency Response & Spill

Prevention Control & Countermeasure Plan in order to

facilitate response efforts in the event of an off-site

anhydrous ammonia release.  Included in the ERSPCC are

measures to be taken internally by Cherry Growers, Inc as

well as measures to be taken by off-site response agencies.



Cherry Growers, Inc has trained approximately four on-site

personnel to respond to accidental ammonia releases.  These

personnel are trained in accordance with 29 CFR, OSHA's

hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations

according to their duties and function.  These personnel

receive initial training and annual update training

thereafter.  In addition, simulations of emergency releases

with off-site effects are conducted periodically too test

the skills of Cherry Growers, Inc HazMat team.  Each

simulation is critiqued and changes are made to the

Emergency Response plan as appropriate.



To assure that the local governmental r

esponse agencies are

familiar with Cherry Growers, Inc emergency response

procedures, the company has submitted copies of the ERSPCC

for review and approval by the local agencies.  The

following agencies have reviewed and approved Cherry Growers

Inc Emergency Response Plan:



u    Grand Traverse County Fire Department



u    County LEPC Committee Chairperson



u    Grand Traverse County Emergency Management Department



u    Northwest Regional HazMat Team



To plan for an ammonia release with off-site effects, Cherry

Growers, Inc SOP includes procedures/equipment to mitigate

the release, procedures to inform local response agencies,

transportation maps for response agencies, evacuation route

maps, and procedures for public communication.



In addition to the above local agencies, Cherry Growers, Inc

has arranged emergency response assistance with a local

clean-up contractor.



In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site

effects, the general public will be warned using the

following methods:



u    Broadcast message via the local television and radio

  stations by the County LEPC.



u    Sirens



u    Police and fire vehicles equipped with public address

  systems, and



u    Door-to-door notification of residents by local

  officials (if time permits).



As backup measures, Cherry Growers, Inc has arranged

emergency response assistance with a local clean-up

contractor.  The Fire Departments and LEPC has arranged for

back-up assistance from another local environmental clean-up

contractor.



Continuing Efforts to Improve Safety



As part of the Cherry Growers Inc continuous efforts to

improve the performance of its safety system, several

changes are planned at the facility to improve safety and

prevent anhydrous ammonia releases.  These changes are

scheduled to be implemented over the next six months and

include equipment upgrades, enhanced operating procedures,

additional training and education.
